question: [File: accounts/abi/abi.go] [Function: JSON()] [DoS Attack] Can an attacker provide an extremely large JSON payload through the io.Reader that causes memory exhaustion during json.NewDecoder().Decode(), potentially crashing validator nodes and disrupting block production? (High)

[File: accounts/abi/abi.go] [Function: JSON()] [DoS Attack] Does the JSON decoder have any limits on recursion depth or nested structure complexity, or can an attacker craft deeply nested JSON structures that cause stack overflow during parsing, leading to node crashes? (High)

[File: accounts/abi/abi.go] [Function: JSON()] [Input Validation] Can malformed JSON with invalid UTF-8 sequences or null bytes cause the decoder to panic or produce corrupted ABI structures that lead to incorrect transaction execution? (Medium)

[File: accounts/abi/abi.go] [Function: JSON()] [State Corruption] If the JSON decoder returns a partial ABI structure on error, does the calling code properly validate the ABI completeness before using it for transaction processing, or could incomplete ABIs lead to incorrect state transitions? (High)

[File: accounts/abi/abi.go] [Function: JSON()] [Resource Exhaustion] Can an attacker provide JSON with extremely long string values in method/event names that consume excessive memory when allocated, causing memory pressure on validator nodes? (Medium)

[File: accounts/abi/abi.go] [Function: Pack()] [Method ID Collision] When packing constructor calls with empty name, does the function properly handle the case where Constructor.Inputs is nil, or could this cause a nil pointer dereference leading to node crashes during transaction construction? (High)

[File: accounts/abi/abi.go] [Function: Pack()] [Method Lookup] Can an attacker exploit the method lookup logic by providing method names with special characters or extremely long names that cause performance degradation or hash collisions in the Methods map? (Medium)

[File: accounts/abi/abi.go] [Function: Pack()] [Data Manipulation] Does the append operation that combines method.ID and arguments properly validate that method.ID is exactly 4 bytes, or could corrupted ABI definitions lead to invalid transaction data that passes initial validation but fails during execution? (High)

[File: accounts/abi/abi.go] [Function: Pack()] [Integer Overflow] When appending method.ID to arguments, could extremely large argument data cause integer overflow in slice capacity calculations, leading to memory corruption or incorrect transaction encoding? (Medium)

[File: accounts/abi/abi.go] [Function: Pack()] [Error Handling] If method.Inputs.Pack() returns an error but has already allocated large amounts of memory, is that memory properly released, or could repeated failed pack attempts cause memory leaks in validator nodes? (Medium)

[File: accounts/abi/abi.go] [Function: Pack()] [Method Not Found] When a method name doesn't exist in abi.Methods, does the error message potentially leak sensitive information about the contract's internal structure that could aid attackers in reconnaissance? (Low)

[File: accounts/abi/abi.go] [Function: getArguments()] [Data Length Validation] The modulo check 'len(data)%32 != 0' only validates output data for methods but not for events - can an attacker exploit this inconsistency by providing event data with non-32-byte alignment that causes incorrect parsing downstream? (High)

[File: accounts/abi/abi.go] [Function: getArguments()] [Naming Collision] Since the function checks both Methods and Events maps for the same name, can an attacker create a contract with identically named methods and events that causes ambiguous argument selection and incorrect data unpacking? (Medium)

[File: accounts/abi/abi.go] [Function: getArguments()] [Priority Confusion] The function checks abi.Methods before abi.Events - can this ordering be exploited to force method output unpacking when event unpacking was intended, leading to type confusion and incorrect state interpretation? (Medium)

[File: accounts/abi/abi.go] [Function: getArguments()] [Nil Return] When both method and event lookups fail and args is nil, does the calling code properly check for nil before dereferencing, or could this cause panic conditions in transaction processing paths? (High)

[File: accounts/abi/abi.go] [Function: getArguments()] [Error Message] The error message format reveals internal state - could repeated queries with various names be used to enumerate all available methods and events, violating contract privacy assumptions? (Low)

[File: accounts/abi/abi.go] [Function: Unpack()] [Error Propagation] Does the function properly sanitize error messages from args.Unpack() that might contain sensitive decoded data, or could error logs leak private information from failed transaction attempts? (Low)

[File: accounts/abi/abi.go] [Function: Unpack()] [Return Type] The function returns []interface{} - can type assertion errors in calling code cause panics if the unpacked data doesn't match expected types, potentially crashing nodes during transaction validation? (High)

[File: accounts/abi/abi.go] [Function: Unpack()] [Memory Allocation] For large data payloads, does args.Unpack() have memory limits, or can an attacker provide transaction data that causes unbounded memory allocation during unpacking, leading to DoS? (High)

[File: accounts/abi/abi.go] [Function: UnpackIntoInterface()] [Type Safety] The function accepts interface{} for v parameter - can an attacker exploit reflection operations in args.Copy() by providing unexpected types that cause panics or memory corruption? (High)

[File: accounts/abi/abi.go] [Function: UnpackIntoInterface()] [Double Allocation] The function unpacks data into a temporary slice then copies to v - can this double allocation be exploited with large payloads to cause memory exhaustion in nodes processing many transactions? (Medium)

[File: accounts/abi/abi.go] [Function: UnpackIntoInterface()] [Race Condition] If v is a shared structure accessed by multiple goroutines, could concurrent calls to UnpackIntoInterface() cause race conditions in args.Copy() leading to corrupted state? (High)

[File: accounts/abi/abi.go] [Function: UnpackIntoInterface()] [Partial Copy] If args.Copy() fails partway through, could v be left in a partially modified state that causes incorrect transaction execution or state corruption? (High)

[File: accounts/abi/abi.go] [Function: UnpackIntoMap()] [Nil Map] If the provided map v is nil, does args.UnpackIntoMap() properly handle it or attempt to write to nil map causing panic and node crash? (High)

[File: accounts/abi/abi.go] [Function: UnpackIntoMap()] [Map Collision] Can an attacker craft ABI data where argument names collide with existing map keys, causing unexpected overwrites of critical data in the caller's map? (Medium)

[File: accounts/abi/abi.go] [Function: UnpackIntoMap()] [Concurrent Map Access] If the map v is accessed concurrently by other goroutines, could the write operations in UnpackIntoMap cause 'concurrent map writes' panic crashing the node? (High)

[File: accounts/abi/abi.go] [Function: UnpackIntoMap()] [Memory Growth] For contracts with many arguments, does repeated unpacking into the same map without clearing cause unbounded memory growth as keys accumulate? (Medium)

[File: accounts/abi/abi.go] [Function: UnmarshalJSON()] [Map Initialization] The function initializes Methods, Events, and Errors maps - if UnmarshalJSON is called multiple times on the same ABI instance, could this cause memory leaks from unreferenced old maps? (Medium)

[File: accounts/abi/abi.go] [Function: UnmarshalJSON()] [Constructor Validation] When Type is 'constructor', does the function validate that only one constructor is defined, or could multiple constructor definitions cause ambiguous behavior in contract deployment? (High)

[File: accounts/abi/abi.go] [Function: UnmarshalJSON()] [Fallback Duplication] The function checks HasFallback() and returns error for duplicate fallbacks - but is this check race-safe if multiple goroutines unmarshal ABIs concurrently, potentially allowing duplicate fallbacks to be registered? (High)

[File: accounts/abi/abi.go] [Function: UnmarshalJSON()] [Receive Validation] For 'receive' type, the function validates StateMutability must be 'payable' - but what if StateMutability is empty string or unexpected value, could this bypass validation allowing non-payable receive functions? (High)

[File: accounts/abi/abi.go] [Function: UnmarshalJSON()] [Event Name Conflict] The function uses ResolveNameConflict for events - but can an attacker craft JSON with events that intentionally collide forcing name mangling that breaks event log parsing in dependent contracts? (Medium)

[File: accounts/abi/abi.go] [Function: UnmarshalJSON()] [Method Name Conflict] Similar to events, method name conflict resolution could be exploited - can an attacker create methods with colliding names that result in the wrong method being called during transaction execution? (High)

[File: accounts/abi/abi.go] [Function: UnmarshalJSON()] [Type Switch Exhaustion] The switch statement handles constructor, function, fallback, receive, event, error types - but what if a future Solidity version introduces new types, could unhandled types cause the function to skip critical validation? (Medium)

[File: accounts/abi/abi.go] [Function: UnmarshalJSON()] [Error Override] Error types use field.Name directly without conflict resolution - can an attacker create multiple errors with the same name that override each other, hiding critical error conditions? (Medium)

[File: accounts/abi/abi.go] [Function: UnmarshalJSON()] [Anonymous Field] The Anonymous field is only checked for events - could setting Anonymous on other types cause unexpected behavior in event filtering or method lookup? (Low)

[File: accounts/abi/abi.go] [Function: UnmarshalJSON()] [StateMutability Validation] The function passes StateMutability to NewMethod without validating it's a recognized value ('pure', 'view', 'nonpayable', 'payable') - can invalid values cause incorrect gas estimation or execution behavior? (Medium)

[File: accounts/abi/abi.go] [Function: UnmarshalJSON()] [Constant/Payable Flags] Both Constant and Payable deprecated flags are passed to NewMethod - can conflicting flag combinations (both true) cause ambiguous method classification leading to incorrect execution? (Medium)

[File: accounts/abi/abi.go] [Function: UnmarshalJSON()] [Inputs/Outputs Validation] Does the function validate that Inputs and Outputs arrays are not excessively large, or could an attacker define methods with thousands of parameters causing memory exhaustion during ABI parsing? (High)

[File: accounts/abi/abi.go] [Function: UnmarshalJSON()] [JSON Array Processing] The function iterates over fields array without bounds checking - can a maliciously large JSON array cause excessive iteration time leading to DoS during ABI loading? (Medium)

[File: accounts/abi/abi.go] [Function: MethodById()] [Short Data] The function checks len(sigdata) < 4 - but what if sigdata is exactly 4 bytes of all zeros, could this match an unexpected method or cause confusion in method dispatch? (Low)

[File: accounts/abi/abi.go] [Function: MethodById()] [Linear Search] The function performs linear search through all methods - can an attacker define contracts with thousands of methods causing O(n) lookup time that degrades transaction processing performance? (Medium)

[File: accounts/abi/abi.go] [Function: MethodById()] [Method ID Collision] Does the function detect when multiple methods have the same 4-byte ID (hash collision), or would it return the first match potentially calling the wrong method and causing state corruption? (Critical)

[File: accounts/abi/abi.go] [Function: MethodById()] [Slice Bounds] The sigdata[:4] slice operation - if sigdata length changes between the length check and slice, could this cause out-of-bounds panic in concurrent scenarios? (Medium)

[File: accounts/abi/abi.go] [Function: MethodById()] [Return Pointer] The function returns *Method pointer - if the Methods map is modified after lookup, could the returned pointer become invalid leading to use-after-free type bugs? (High)

[File: accounts/abi/abi.go] [Function: MethodById()] [Error Format] The error message includes raw sigdata[:4] bytes - could this leak sensitive information about attempted method calls in validator logs? (Low)

[File: accounts/abi/abi.go] [Function: EventByID()] [Linear Search] Similar to MethodById, linear search through Events map - can contracts with excessive events cause performance degradation in log processing and event filtering? (Medium)

[File: accounts/abi/abi.go] [Function: EventByID()] [Hash Comparison] The function uses bytes.Equal on full 32-byte hashes - but are there known hash collision attacks on Keccak256 that could cause event confusion? (Low)

[File: accounts/abi/abi.go] [Function: EventByID()] [Event ID Collision] If multiple events have the same topic hash (unlikely but possible with hash collisions), does the function detect this or return the first match potentially misparsing event logs? (High)

[File: accounts/abi/abi.go] [Function: EventByID()] [Return Pointer] Returns *Event pointer - if Events map is concurrently modified, could the pointer become invalid causing use-after-free scenarios? (High)

[File: accounts/abi/abi.go] [Function: EventByID()] [Common.Hash Type] The function accepts common.Hash - does this properly validate that the hash is exactly 32 bytes, or could malformed hashes cause comparison errors? (Low)

[File: accounts/abi/abi.go] [Function: HasFallback()] [Type Check Only] The function only checks if Fallback.Type == Fallback - but what if Fallback is partially initialized with Type set but other fields invalid, could this cause issues in fallback execution? (Medium)

[File: accounts/abi/abi.go] [Function: HasFallback()] [Zero Value Check] If abi.Fallback is the zero value, does Type default to 0 (Constructor), or could this cause false negatives in fallback detection? (Low)

[File: accounts/abi/abi.go] [Function: HasReceive()] [Type Check Only] Similar to HasFallback, only checks Type field - could partially initialized Receive cause issues in plain ether transfer handling? (Medium)

[File: accounts/abi/abi.go] [Function: HasReceive()] [Receive vs Fallback] If both HasReceive and HasFallback return true, is there clear precedence in which gets called for plain ether transfers, or could this cause ambiguous execution? (High)

[File: accounts/abi/abi.go] [Function: UnpackRevert()] [Selector Validation] The function checks for exact revertSelector match - but can an attacker craft data that starts with revert selector but contains malicious payload causing incorrect revert reason parsing? (Medium)

[File: accounts/abi/abi.go] [Function: UnpackRevert()] [Short Data] Checks len(data) < 4 - but what if data is exactly 4 bytes (just selector), does unpacking data[4:] on empty slice cause issues? (Medium)

[File: accounts/abi/abi.go] [Function: UnpackRevert()] [Type Creation] Creates new Type for 'string' - if NewType fails, is the error properly propagated or could nil Type cause panic in Arguments.Unpack? (High)

[File: accounts/abi/abi.go] [Function: UnpackRevert()] [Type Assertion] The function performs type assertion unpacked[0].(string) - what if unpacking succeeds but returns non-string type, could this panic crash the node? (High)

[File: accounts/abi/abi.go] [Function: UnpackRevert()] [Large Strings] For extremely long revert reason strings, does the unpacking have size limits, or could an attacker cause memory exhaustion by reverting with massive strings? (High)

[File: accounts/abi/abi.go] [Function: UnpackRevert()] [Revert Selector Global] The revertSelector is a package-level variable computed once - is this thread-safe if multiple goroutines access it concurrently during transaction processing? (Low)

[File: accounts/abi/abi.go] [Function: UnpackRevert()] [Index Bounds] Accesses unpacked[0] without checking array length - if Unpack returns empty array, could this cause index out of bounds panic? (High)

[File: accounts/abi/abi.go] [Struct: ABI] [Map Concurrent Access] The Methods, Events, and Errors maps - are these protected by any locks, or could concurrent reads during transaction processing and writes during ABI updates cause race conditions? (Critical)

[File: accounts/abi/abi.go] [Struct: ABI] [Constructor Field] The Constructor field is a single Method - can contracts with multiple constructors cause confusion or is this enforced during UnmarshalJSON? (Medium)

[File: accounts/abi/abi.go] [Struct: ABI] [Fallback vs Receive] The comment notes Fallback represents legacy fallback - can mixing legacy and new-style fallback/receive cause execution ambiguity in contract calls? (Medium)
[File: accounts/abi/abi.go] [Struct: ABI] [Map Nil Values] Could any of the map values (Method, Event, Error) be nil, causing nil pointer dereference when accessed in transaction processing? (High)

[File: accounts/abi/abi.go] [Cross-Function] [Pack then MethodById] If Pack() is called with one method name and MethodById() is called with the resulting data, could method ID collisions cause a different method to be identified leading to incorrect execution? (Critical)

[File: accounts/abi/abi.go] [Cross-Function] [UnmarshalJSON then Pack] After unmarshaling ABI from potentially malicious JSON, could crafted method definitions cause Pack() to generate invalid transaction data that passes initial validation but corrupts state? (Critical)

[File: accounts/abi/abi.go] [Cross-Function] [Pack then Unpack] Does packing then unpacking the same data produce identical values for all types, or could precision loss or encoding differences cause state inconsistencies? (High)

[File: accounts/abi/abi.go] [Cross-Function] [Multiple Unpack Calls] If Unpack(), UnpackIntoInterface(), and UnpackIntoMap() are called on the same data with the same ABI, do they produce consistent results or could implementation differences cause parsing discrepancies? (High)

[File: accounts/abi/abi.go] [Cross-Function] [EventByID then Unpack] After looking up event by ID, could event.Inputs have nil or invalid arguments that cause Unpack to panic when processing event logs? (High)

[File: accounts/abi/abi.go] [Memory Safety] [Slice Capacity] Throughout the file, append operations are used - could repeatedly appending to slices cause excessive memory allocations and fragmentation in long-running validator nodes? (Medium)

[File: accounts/abi/abi.go] [Memory Safety] [String Allocation] Methods and event names are strings stored in maps - for contracts with many methods, could this cause significant memory overhead? (Low)

[File: accounts/abi/abi.go] [Memory Safety] [Interface{} Boxing] Functions return []interface{} which requires boxing - could this cause heap allocations impacting performance in high-throughput transaction processing? (Low)

[File: accounts/abi/abi.go] [Memory Safety] [JSON Decoder] The json.NewDecoder in JSON() reads from io.Reader - if the reader doesn't implement proper buffering, could this cause excessive small reads impacting performance? (Low)

[File: accounts/abi/abi.go] [Integer Safety] [Data Length] The check 'len(data)%32 != 0' - for extremely large data lengths close to int overflow, could the modulo operation behave unexpectedly? (Low)
[File: accounts/abi/abi.go] [Integer Safety] [Slice Indexing] The sigdata[:4] operation - on platforms where int is 32-bit, could extremely large slices cause index overflow? (Low)
[File: accounts/abi/abi.go] [Integer Safety] [Method ID] Method.ID is 4 bytes - are there any operations that assume it fits in uint32 that could overflow on unexpected values? (Low)

[File: accounts/abi/abi.go] [Panic Safety] [Map Access] Accessing Methods[name] and Events[name] - if done concurrently with map modifications, could this trigger 'concurrent map read and map write' panic? (Critical)
[File: accounts/abi/abi.go] [Panic Safety] [Slice Bounds] Multiple [:4] slice operations - if any length checks are bypassed due to race conditions, could these cause slice bounds panic? (High)

[File: accounts/abi/abi.go] [Panic Safety] [Type Assertion] UnpackRevert() performs type assertion - if this fails, does it panic or return error, and could unhandled panics crash validator nodes? (High)

[File: accounts/abi/abi.go] [Panic Safety] [Nil Pointer] Throughout the file, returned pointers (*Method, *Event) - are there code paths that could dereference these without nil checks causing panics? (High)
[File: accounts/abi/abi.go] [Error Handling] [JSON Decode Error] If json.Decode() returns error in JSON(), is the partially decoded ABI struct in a valid state or corrupted? (Medium)

[File: accounts/abi/abi.go] [Error Handling] [Pack Error Propagation] When method.Inputs.Pack() fails in Pack(), does the error provide enough context for debugging without leaking sensitive contract details? (Low)
[File: accounts/abi/abi.go] [Error Handling] [Unpack Error Recovery] If args.Unpack() fails partway through, are allocated resources properly cleaned up or could this cause memory leaks? (Medium)
[File: accounts/abi/abi.go] [Error Handling] [Silent Failures] Are there any error conditions that are silently ignored, potentially masking critical issues in transaction processing? (High)

[File: accounts/abi/abi.go] [Race Condition] [ABI Struct Modification] If one goroutine calls UnmarshalJSON() while another calls Pack() or Unpack(), could concurrent map access cause data races or panics? (Critical)

[File: accounts/abi/abi.go] [Race Condition] [Method Lookup] In MethodById(), iterating over Methods map while another goroutine modifies it could cause non-deterministic behavior or crashes. (Critical)
[File: accounts/abi/abi.go] [Race Condition] [Event Lookup] Similarly, EventByID() concurrent with map modifications could cause races. (Critical)
[File: accounts/abi/abi.go] [Race Condition] [Shared Return Values] When returning *Method or *Event pointers, if the underlying structs are modified, could readers see inconsistent state? (High)

[File: accounts/abi/abi.go] [Validator Attack] [ABI Manipulation] Can a malicious validator craft custom ABIs for the mint contract that bypass mint limits by using incorrect method signatures that still pass initial validation? (Critical)

[File: accounts/abi/abi.go] [Validator Attack] [Method ID Manipulation] Could a compromised validator generate transactions with method IDs that don't match actual method hashes, causing incorrect method dispatch in the mint contract? (Critical)

[File: accounts/abi/abi.go] [Validator Attack] [Event Log Forgery] Can a malicious validator create event logs with manipulated topic hashes that EventByID() accepts but represent different events, causing incorrect burn tracking? (High)

[File: accounts/abi/abi.go] [Validator Attack] [Fallback Abuse] Could a compromised validator send ether to contracts without triggering the correct fallback/receive function by manipulating the ABI representation? (High)

[File: accounts/abi/abi.go] [Transaction Impact] [Invalid Method Call] If MethodById() returns an error during transaction processing, does the transaction get properly rejected or could it consume gas without state changes? (Medium)

[File: accounts/abi/abi.go] [Transaction Impact] [Unpack Failure] When Unpack() fails on transaction return data, does this cause transaction revert or could it lead to inconsistent state between execution and logs? (High)

[File: accounts/abi/abi.go] [Transaction Impact] [Constructor Packing] If Pack() with empty name fails during contract deployment, could this leave the blockchain in an inconsistent state with deployed code but failed constructor? (High)

[File: accounts/abi/abi.go] [Transaction Impact] [Revert Parsing] If UnpackRevert() fails to parse revert reason, does this prevent proper error reporting or could it hide critical contract failures from users? (Medium)

[File: accounts/abi/abi.go] [State Corruption] [Argument Mismatch] If getArguments() returns arguments for a method when event arguments were expected (or vice versa), could subsequent unpacking corrupt state or logs? (High)

[File: accounts/abi/abi.go] [State Corruption] [Type Confusion] Can Pack() accept arguments of wrong types that get encoded incorrectly but pass validation, leading to state corruption when the transaction executes? (Critical)

[File: accounts/abi/abi.go] [State Corruption] [Partial Unpack] If UnpackIntoInterface() or UnpackIntoMap() fail partway through, could partially written data cause state inconsistencies in contract storage? (High)
[File: accounts/abi/abi.go] [State Corruption] [Method Confusion] Could method name conflicts resolved by ResolveNameConflict cause the wrong method to execute, corrupting contract state? (High)
[File: accounts/abi/abi.go] [DoS Attack] [JSON Bomb] Can an attacker provide a highly compressed JSON payload that expands to gigabytes during parsing in JSON(), exhausting validator memory? (High)

[File: accounts/abi/abi.go] [DoS Attack] [Method Iteration] With contracts having thousands of methods, could MethodById() linear search cause CPU exhaustion when processing many transactions? (Medium)
[File: accounts/abi/abi.go] [DoS Attack] [Event Iteration] Similarly, EventByID() on contracts with many events could cause log processing DoS. (Medium)

[File: accounts/abi/abi.go] [DoS Attack] [Repeated Unpacking] Could an attacker flood the network with transactions containing large data payloads that require expensive unpacking operations, overwhelming validator CPU? (High)
[File: accounts/abi/abi.go] [DoS Attack] [Revert String Size] Can extremely long revert reason strings in UnpackRevert() cause memory exhaustion or log storage issues? (Medium)
[File: accounts/abi/abi.go] [Cryptographic] [Method ID Generation] The 4-byte method ID is derived from Keccak256 hash - are there known preimage attacks that could allow method ID spoofing? (Low)
[File: accounts/abi/abi.go] [Cryptographic] [Event Topic Hash] Event IDs use full Keccak256 hash - but are 32 bytes sufficient to prevent birthday attacks in event ID collision? (Low)

[File: accounts/abi/abi.go] [Cryptographic] [Hash Collision] If two different method signatures produce the same 4-byte ID prefix, does MethodById() have any secondary validation to detect this? (High)

[File: accounts/abi/abi.go] [Data Integrity] [ABI Consistency] If the same contract is loaded from different JSON sources, could differences in field ordering cause different Method/Event map iterations leading to non-deterministic behavior? (High)

[File: accounts/abi/abi.go] [Data Integrity] [Round-Trip Encoding] Does packing a value then unpacking it guarantee bit-perfect reproduction for all types, or could encoding differences cause state drift? (High)

[File: accounts/abi/abi.go] [Data Integrity] [Map Ordering] Since Go maps have randomized iteration order, could this cause non-deterministic behavior when iterating Methods or Events in consensus-critical code? (Critical)
[File: accounts/abi/abi.go] [Edge Case] [Empty ABI] What happens if an ABI with zero methods, events, and errors is created - could empty maps cause unexpected behavior in dependent code? (Medium)

[File: accounts/abi/abi.go] [Edge Case] [All Functions] If a contract defines constructor, functions, fallback, receive, events, and errors all at once, does the ABI handle this correctly or could resource limits be exceeded? (Medium)
[File: accounts/abi/abi.go] [Edge Case] [Unicode Names] Can method or event names contain Unicode characters, and if so, could Unicode normalization issues cause name matching problems? (Medium)
[File: accounts/abi/abi.go] [Edge Case] [Zero-Length Data] What happens when Pack() or Unpack() is called with zero-length data - could this cause unexpected behavior or panics? (Medium)

[File: accounts/abi/abi.go] [Edge Case] [Maximum Methods] Is there a practical limit on the number of methods in the Methods map, or could contracts with millions of methods cause performance degradation? (Medium)

[File: accounts/abi/abi.go] [Mint Contract] [ABI Tampering] Could a malicious actor modify the mint contract's ABI in memory to bypass mint limits by altering method signatures or parameters before Pack() is called? (Critical)

[File: accounts/abi/abi.go] [Mint Contract] [Event Filtering] If the mint contract emits events, could EventByID() failures cause burn events from external chains to be missed, breaking the bridge? (Critical)
[File: accounts/abi/abi.go] [Mint Contract] [Constructor Attack] During mint contract deployment, could malicious constructor parameters packed via Pack() bypass initialization checks? (High)
[File: accounts/abi/abi.go] [Mint Contract] [Method Call Validation] Does the ABI validation prevent calling administrative mint functions with forged method IDs? (Critical)
[File: accounts/abi/abi.go] [Resource Exhaustion] [String Interning] Are method/event name strings interned or could duplicate strings across many ABIs cause memory bloat? (Low)

[File: accounts/abi/abi.go] [Resource Exhaustion] [Map Growth] Do the Methods/Events/Errors maps ever shrink, or do they only grow as more ABIs are loaded, potentially exhausting memory over time? (Medium)
[File: accounts/abi/abi.go] [Resource Exhaustion] [Argument Slices] Are Inputs/Outputs argument slices reused or is new memory allocated for each unpacking operation? (Low)
